repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
---@param bufnr? integer Buffer number to resolve. Defaults to current buffer
```

The optional marker goes on the argument name, not type, and parens are no longer needed. Please change that everywhere.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -78,7 +78,7 @@ end
 
 --- Returns the buffer number for the given {bufnr}.
 ---
----@param bufnr (integer|nil) Buffer number to resolve. Defaults to current buffer
+---@param bufnr (integer?) Buffer number to resolve. Defaults to current buffer

comment_data.body: Except return type; there it's correct, I think.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -78,7 +78,7 @@ end
 
 --- Returns the buffer number for the given {bufnr}.
 ---
----@param bufnr (integer|nil) Buffer number to resolve. Defaults to current buffer
+---@param bufnr (integer?) Buffer number to resolve. Defaults to current buffer

comment_data.body:
It can go on both. When on the type it indicates the value may be nil but should be provided, and when on the arg name it indicates the argument is completely optional.

In practice, LuaLS won't ever be able to check this, but there is a semantic difference. In Lua you can detect the number of call arguments with `select('#', ...)` for vararg functions which will give you 2 for `foo(nil, nil)`.

With that said, we should probably prefer the `?` on the arg name like you suggested.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -78,7 +78,7 @@ end
 
 --- Returns the buffer number for the given {bufnr}.
 ---
----@param bufnr (integer|nil) Buffer number to resolve. Defaults to current buffer
+---@param bufnr (integer?) Buffer number to resolve. Defaults to current buffer

comment_data.body:
I believe it makes a difference for the dreaded "missing field" diagnostic, which somewhat triggered this push...

(Apart from that, my argument is mostly from consistency and "neatness", I have to admit.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -78,7 +78,7 @@ end
 
 --- Returns the buffer number for the given {bufnr}.
 ---
----@param bufnr (integer|nil) Buffer number to resolve. Defaults to current buffer
+---@param bufnr (integer?) Buffer number to resolve. Defaults to current buffer

comment_data.body: looks like there are some problems with docgen now?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -708,7 +708,7 @@ buf_request_sync({bufnr}, {method}, {params}, {timeout_ms})
 
     Return (multiple): ~
         (table) result Map of client_id:request_result.
-        (string|nil) err On timeout, cancel, or error, `err` is a string
+        string?|nil err On timeout, cancel, or error, `err` is a string

comment_data.body:
Yes. I plan on looking into this tomorrow evening. I don't have time today due to work.

I don't know anything about docgen, so hopefully there is some flag to disable the manually appending `|nil` behavior.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -708,7 +708,7 @@ buf_request_sync({bufnr}, {method}, {params}, {timeout_ms})
 
     Return (multiple): ~
         (table) result Map of client_id:request_result.
-        (string|nil) err On timeout, cancel, or error, `err` is a string
+        string?|nil err On timeout, cancel, or error, `err` is a string

comment_data.body:
The docgen is an ad-hoc flow that is developed just enough for it to work. You'll need to dig into the doxygen filter so it can handle `?`.

This is partly why I haven't already converted everything to `?`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -708,7 +708,7 @@ buf_request_sync({bufnr}, {method}, {params}, {timeout_ms})
 
     Return (multiple): ~
         (table) result Map of client_id:request_result.
-        (string|nil) err On timeout, cancel, or error, `err` is a string
+        string?|nil err On timeout, cancel, or error, `err` is a string

comment_data.body: Hmm. _Some_ `?` already work, otherwise I wouldn't have suggested this.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -708,7 +708,7 @@ buf_request_sync({bufnr}, {method}, {params}, {timeout_ms})
 
     Return (multiple): ~
         (table) result Map of client_id:request_result.
-        (string|nil) err On timeout, cancel, or error, `err` is a string
+        string?|nil err On timeout, cancel, or error, `err` is a string

comment_regular_data.body:
I see the failed build for not pushing updated docs. I will do that later today, and also look at some of the incorrectly generated types. 

EDIT: I will also troubleshoot the failed BSD build.
The runners are often flaky; for the purpose of this PR, I would not worry about it unless they all fail. (But since you only change comments, that should not be the case.)

labels.description: changes that are not features or bugfixes
labels.name: refactor

title: refactor(types): replace `|nil` with `?` for LSP runtime
